definition[0]: to expect that something will happen and be ready for it
example[1]: A good speaker is able to anticipate an audience’s needs and concerns.
example[2]: The schedule isn’t final, but we don’t anticipate many changes.
example[4]: This year, we anticipate that our expenses will be 15% greater.
example[5]: It is anticipated that the research will have many different practical applications.
example[6]: I didn’t anticipate having to do the cooking myself!
definition[1]: to think about something that is going to happen, especially something pleasant
example[7]: Daniel was eagerly anticipating her arrival.
definition[2]: to do something before someone else
example[8]: Copernicus anticipated in part the discoveries of the 17th and 18th centuries.
explanation[1]: You anticipate that something will happen
example[10]: No one could have anticipated that this would happen
explanation[3]: You expect that something will happen, or someone will do something
example[12]: Everyone expected that the team would win
explanation[4]: You expect something to happen, or expect someone to do something
example[14]: No one could have predicted the result
explanation[6]: You  predict that something will happen, or someone will do something
example[15]: He predicted that the team would win
